p: A study on receptor neuron discrimination of α-pinene and limonene enantiomers in the pine weevil ( Hylobius abietis) reported that one olfactory receptor neuron showed a stronger response to the (+)-α-pinene than to (−)-α-pinene, while another neuron responded to limonene enantiomers vice versa. The study concluded that the enantiomeric ratios of volatile compounds may be important in host location by the pine weevil [ 25]. Studies of effects of methyl jasmonate-induced monoterpenes in Scots pine and Norway spruce tissues showed that (−)-β-pinene had a deterrent effect against Hylobius abietis, however, the effect depended on the (−)-β-pinene/(−)-α-pinene ratio being higher in pine than in spruce [ 26]. The common pine shoot beetle ( Tomicus piniperda), which is reported to be the second most destructive shoot-feeding species in Europe [ 27], was most attracted to Pinus nigra laricio, emitting most (−)-α-pinene [ 28].
